children.subject: I just want to brush it off since I cannot travel abroad this winter. I want to do other things when returning campus.

Why did you take GRE as a freshman? My understanding is that GRE scores aren't important (or even required in many cases), and research is mainly prioritized. If they are looked at, it's probably just to see that you're meeting their threshold.

history.content:
I took GRE general test recently as a freshman and received a score not good but not bad. May I receive some suggestions on whether to take it again? Since I know GRE is a relatively trivial factor in PhD admission, I just prepared for 2 weeks and expected to get a barely minimum score.

I'm a freshman so I have plenty of time to retake it. However, I personally don't like standardized tests and want to allot more time to research. I would rather work on my research project and travel over my next summer and winter holidays. My intended area of grad study is computational/theoretical neuroscience and general AI, and my dream school is Stanford's Wu Tsai Neuroscience Institute. If my improvement on GRE from 328 + 4 to 330 + 5 should provide me with a statistically significant advantage, then I will take GRE again to improve.

Besides, I'm an intended triple major on CS, Stats, and CogSci, and have started remote research already. If I could have several reasonable publications and also with me as the first author before senior, do I still need to work on GRE?

[Sorry...I just don't want to take GRE again...But for the sake of advantage on grad school application, then I will do.]
history.subject: Whether to retake GRE?
